ly have a growth of small cedars
and grass. It was under the sheltering ledges of rock near the summits of these mesas that the ancient cliff dwellers built their
cities. Protected from the marauding Indians of the plains,
these people could tend their flocks
on the flat tops of their home
mountains with comparative safety. Their houses were substantially built and with little trouble
they have been partially or totally restored by the government.
The present inhabitants of the
plateau are mostly Indians and
Mexicans. They are a rugged race,
the men especially being of unusual stamina. Dr. Atwood described a race in which the contestants kicked small sticks all the
way around the base of one of the
mesas with their bare Wes, covering the distance of about ten miles
in about an hour.
President Atwood closed his
talk by giving a graphic' account
of the wonders of the Grand Canyon of the Colorado. He showed
numerous lantern slides during his
entire talk, those of the Grand
Canyon being unusually interesting and beautiful.
After the address Tom Jenifer,
secretary of the Interfraternity
Board, presented the Scholarship
Cup to the Beta Theta Pi fraternity. The cup enters into the permanent possession of this fraternity as they have won it three
times.

exhibition of various engineering

This affair is usually followed
by a large ball held in a hall decorated in green to represent Blarney Castle and the Blarney Stone
mysteriously appears to take its
part in the decorations.
One of the mysterious properties of this Blarney Stone is that
it travels from chapter to chapter,
appearing and disappearing at the
most unexpected times, and it is
claimed no one, not even the highest of the Knigths, knows how it
gets from place to place.
The insignia of the organization
consists of a green shamrock
across which is a little slide-rule,
This emblem is usually attached
by a small gold chain to the regular class pin.
The Hopkins chapter, if established before the end of the year
will make its first public appearance on March 17.

Dr. Willoughby stopped off in
Egypt in order to observe politicl condition, his specialty, in
that country. While he was in
Egypt, England lifted her suzerainty, thus making Egypt entire
sovereign. Before this time it was
impossible for anyone to determine the political status of Egypt.
declared
England
that
she
(Egypt) was sovereign with the
exception of certain restrictions
which would eventually be removed. These resstrictions were
removed while Dr. Willoughby
was in Egypt and England has
now only the rights of protecting
the Suez Canal and foreign business in the land of the pyramids.
Political Interest in India

In India, according to Dr. Willoughby, the English government
is making an honest attempt to
slowly introduce responsible government. This is being done with
the ultimate of British control
identical with that of the Other dominions of Canada, Australia,
South Africa and Ireland. Many
of the Indians insist that the progress toward Indian autonomy is
too slow and should be more rapid.
There is, therefore, a great deal of
discontent which makes England's
task of introducing responsible
government much more difficult.
PROF. PELLIOT TO LECTURE
ON ARCHAEOLOGY
Professor Paul Pelliot, of the
chair of Chinese Civilization in the
College of France, will deliver four
lectures, open to the public, in the
Civil Engineering Hall on February
the fifth seventh twelfth and fourteenth, at.5 P. M. Professor Pelliot will lecture on the subject of
his archaeological work in Chinese
Turkestan, where many ancient
manuscripts, covered and preserved
by the invading desert, have been
reclaimed. The field chosen by Professor Pelliot for his archaeological
research rivals Egypt in its abundance of ancient records, so at this
time when Central Asia is assuming archaeological importance, the
archaeologist's message should be
intensely interesting.

What
Engineering
Owes To
Sound
Principles
DERITAPS no phase of electrical development is more
fascinating than the events
leading up to the practical use of electricity as the motive power for street
railway transportation.
It is a story of "midnight oil", hard thinking, extreme perseverance. No better example of the value
of sound principles to present day engineering could
be cited than the Westinghouse No. 3 Motor, as introduced in 1891.
Its design was so fundamentally correct and the
details were so soundly worked out that subsequent
developments of railway motors all followed the principles embodied in it. Now let's see what bearing this
has had on modern transportation.
In 1700 the first permanently fixed rails made their
appearance. In 1831, in New York, horse cars began
operation. In 1834, after fruitless attempts to apply
steam, compressed air, gas, etc., to these cars, a
Vermont blacksmith, one Thomas Davenport, sug-

Westinghouse Motor, No. 3, the Progenitor of the
Present Universally-Adopted D.C. Railway Motor.

gested that electricity be used as the motive power.
The very first practical commercial dynamo,built by
Gramme, in 1862, made this suggestion a possibility.
It was natural that George Westinghouse, with his
intense interest in transportation, should take up this
problem. From 1889 to 1891, he, with his organization, worked continuously to perfect a commercially
practicable railway motor, and the famous No. 3,
daddy of all street railway motors, was the result.
As mentioned before,the principles embodied in the
No.3, thirty-two years ago,are still in use, and at least
ten prominent features of this remarkable motor are
to be found in present-day types. A number of these
early motors are still in operation—a tribute to sound

engineering principles.

Since the death of Dr. Basil L. Gildersleeve much has been said
about the poetry of the departed Greek scholar. Little of his verse
found its way to print, but in the last years of his life Dr. Gildersleeve overcame his reluctance to have his verses published and occasionally a local newspaper or a scholar's magazine was fortunate
enough to obtain permission to print some of "the last Greek's" lilting lines. The best known of these, and one of the latest was the
sonnet on his eighty-eighth birthday. The sonnet was written in 1919,
four years before the master's death.
"My eyes are dim from age and dull my ears;
And I am left alone to meditate
Upon the riddles of our mortal state,
Too sad for laughter, and too deep for tears.

"The wane of intellect, and the weight of years,
Said one who knew,'you cannot separate,'
Shall I say yea to this at eighty-eight?
For truth is truth, what if it irks, not cheers?
"No answer to the question can I find,
Nor will I list to friendship's glowing lips,
Which can tell me I am now just what I.was.
This constant watching for the wane of mind
Is it not better than the drear eclipse
When senile meanderin,gs pass for Solon's laws?"

That a professor of Greek should have written poetry of such
depth, and feeling is remarkable, for proficiency in the art only comes
through much practice, even if one has the genius in the first place,
but that it was written at the age of eighty-eight is still more remarkable. Dr. Gildersleeve did not stop writing, however, until just
before his death in his ninety-third year. On November 24 last Dr.
Gildersleeve's old friend and companion in arms, Mr. Joseph Packard died and Dr. Gildersleeve wrote the following verse in his honor:
"The heart knows its own bitterness, 'tis said
Its inliest joys no stranger ever knows:
But from one source the stream of sorrow flows,
And there's one voice for the mourning of the dead.
We weep for those of whom we've only read,
Mourners and mourned may long have found repose,
And yet our hearts are deeply stirred for those
Who in their day would not be comforted.
And so, dear friend of more than fifty years,
Noble exemplar of a noble age,
My tears for thee call forth another's tears
From the sealed fountain of an old Greek page
The sorrows of the world encompass me,
The plangent music of griefs sad, salt sea."

Something Happened in 1891

Interested in Political Conditions

Dr. Willoughby stopped off in
Egypt in order to observe politicl condition, his specialty, in
that country. While he was in
Egypt, England lifted her suzerainty, thus making Egypt entire
sovereign. Before this time it was
impossible for anyone to determine the political status of Egypt.
declared
England
that
she
(Egypt) was sovereign with the
exception of certain restrictions
which would eventually be removed. These resstrictions were
removed while Dr. Willoughby
was in Egypt and England has
now only the rights of protecting
the Suez Canal and foreign business in the land of the pyramids.
Political Interest in India

In India, according to Dr. Willoughby, the English government
is making an honest attempt to
slowly introduce responsible government. This is being done with
the ultimate of British control
identical with that of the Other dominions of Canada, Australia,
South Africa and Ireland. Many
of the Indians insist that the progress toward Indian autonomy is
too slow and should be more rapid.
There is, therefore, a great deal of
discontent which makes England's
task of introducing responsible
government much more difficult.
PROF. PELLIOT TO LECTURE
ON ARCHAEOLOGY
Professor Paul Pelliot, of the
chair of Chinese Civilization in the
College of France, will deliver four
lectures, open to the public, in the
Civil Engineering Hall on February
the fifth seventh twelfth and fourteenth, at.5 P. M. Professor Pelliot will lecture on the subject of
his archaeological work in Chinese
Turkestan, where many ancient
manuscripts, covered and preserved
by the invading desert, have been
reclaimed. The field chosen by Professor Pelliot for his archaeological
research rivals Egypt in its abundance of ancient records, so at this
time when Central Asia is assuming archaeological importance, the
archaeologist's message should be
intensely interesting.

What
Engineering
Owes To
Sound
Principles
DERITAPS no phase of electrical development is more
fascinating than the events
leading up to the practical use of electricity as the motive power for street
railway transportation.
It is a story of "midnight oil", hard thinking, extreme perseverance. No better example of the value
of sound principles to present day engineering could
be cited than the Westinghouse No. 3 Motor, as introduced in 1891.
Its design was so fundamentally correct and the
details were so soundly worked out that subsequent
developments of railway motors all followed the principles embodied in it. Now let's see what bearing this
has had on modern transportation.
In 1700 the first permanently fixed rails made their
appearance. In 1831, in New York, horse cars began
operation. In 1834, after fruitless attempts to apply
steam, compressed air, gas, etc., to these cars, a
Vermont blacksmith, one Thomas Davenport, sug-

Westinghouse Motor, No. 3, the Progenitor of the
Present Universally-Adopted D.C. Railway Motor.

gested that electricity be used as the motive power.
The very first practical commercial dynamo,built by
Gramme, in 1862, made this suggestion a possibility.
It was natural that George Westinghouse, with his
intense interest in transportation, should take up this
problem. From 1889 to 1891, he, with his organization, worked continuously to perfect a commercially
practicable railway motor, and the famous No. 3,
daddy of all street railway motors, was the result.
As mentioned before,the principles embodied in the
No.3, thirty-two years ago,are still in use, and at least
ten prominent features of this remarkable motor are
to be found in present-day types. A number of these
early motors are still in operation—a tribute to sound

engineering principles.

Since the death of Dr. Basil L. Gildersleeve much has been said
about the poetry of the departed Greek scholar. Little of his verse
found its way to print, but in the last years of his life Dr. Gildersleeve overcame his reluctance to have his verses published and occasionally a local newspaper or a scholar's magazine was fortunate
enough to obtain permission to print some of "the last Greek's" lilting lines. The best known of these, and one of the latest was the
sonnet on his eighty-eighth birthday. The sonnet was written in 1919,
four years before the master's death.
"My eyes are dim from age and dull my ears;
And I am left alone to meditate
Upon the riddles of our mortal state,
Too sad for laughter, and too deep for tears.

"The wane of intellect, and the weight of years,
Said one who knew,'you cannot separate,'
Shall I say yea to this at eighty-eight?
For truth is truth, what if it irks, not cheers?
"No answer to the question can I find,
Nor will I list to friendship's glowing lips,
Which can tell me I am now just what I.was.
This constant watching for the wane of mind
Is it not better than the drear eclipse
When senile meanderin,gs pass for Solon's laws?"

That a professor of Greek should have written poetry of such
depth, and feeling is remarkable, for proficiency in the art only comes
through much practice, even if one has the genius in the first place,
but that it was written at the age of eighty-eight is still more remarkable. Dr. Gildersleeve did not stop writing, however, until just
before his death in his ninety-third year. On November 24 last Dr.
Gildersleeve's old friend and companion in arms, Mr. Joseph Packard died and Dr. Gildersleeve wrote the following verse in his honor:
"The heart knows its own bitterness, 'tis said
Its inliest joys no stranger ever knows:
But from one source the stream of sorrow flows,
And there's one voice for the mourning of the dead.
We weep for those of whom we've only read,
Mourners and mourned may long have found repose,
And yet our hearts are deeply stirred for those
Who in their day would not be comforted.
And so, dear friend of more than fifty years,
Noble exemplar of a noble age,
My tears for thee call forth another's tears
From the sealed fountain of an old Greek page
The sorrows of the world encompass me,
The plangent music of griefs sad, salt sea."
